newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya shilling hits new low.
newsitem.headline: Kenya shilling hits new low.

text.p: The Kenyan shilling suffered fresh losses on Monday, touching a new low as foreign investors pulled out of the market amid political and economic uncertainty, commercial bank dealers said.
The shilling depreciated by 1.3 percent on Monday morning to trade at a commercial mean rate of 70.68 from 69.75.
The shilling's latest movements brought its total losses to 18.79 percent since the International Monetary Fund cancelled a key aid package to Kenya citing corruption on July 31.
"It's chaotic right now. We were already at the bottom and now it looks like we're going to begin the slide again," a senior dealer told Reuters.
Dealers said some foreign investors ignored last Friday's appeal by Central Bank of Kenya governor Micah Cheserem not to abandon the Kenyan market.
"Demand is there. Almost five billion shillings of treasury bills from last week's auction were not rolled over and this is what they are looking for," one dealer told Reuters on Monday.

Cheserem, alarmed by a rapid outflow of dollars fuelled by the row with the IMF and pre-election tensions, spoke after investors pulled out of Thursday's usually lucrative weekly auction of high-yield treasury bills citing market uncertainty.
The bank only managed to sell 50 percent of the 14 billion-shilling bills offered.

The IMF's suspension of the $205-million Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF), over concerns on corruption and governance, led the World Bank to delay its own disbursements of up to $71.6 million.
Cheserem has refused to intervene decisively to boost the shilling, saying he would leave the currency to defend itself in the market.
